articles.title: Roadmap for Robotics
articles.excerpt: A comprehensive guide for beginners covering programming languages, development tools, and learning paths for all aspects of robotics.

sections.title: A Common Beginning
sections.content: As a beginner, the most important thing is to start learning a language since it opens up a lot of opportunities in terms of projects to work on. In robotics, different languages have different uses: Python and C++ for automation and ML, C for embedded systems, and MATLAB for modelling.

sections.title: Development Environment
sections.content: Linux is essential for robotics due to its tight integration with tools like ROS. Get comfortable with the Linux terminal, Git for version control, and a good code editor like VS Code.

articles.title: Introduction to Automation
articles.excerpt: Overview of robot automation including planning, controls, and state estimation.
articles.content:
Robots would be pretty useless without having the ability to do stuff on their own. Today, with ever more powerful machine learning techniques, robots are on their way to becoming truly autonomous. Different aspects of Automation include Planning, Controls and State estimation.

Motion planning refers to the computational process of moving from one place to another in the presence of obstacles. The Robot control system directs the motion and sensory processing of a robot. State estimation involves estimating the position and orientation of a robot as it moves through the world using sensors like cameras or laser rangefinders.

articles.title: Setting Up ROS
articles.excerpt: Complete guide to preparing your development environment for ROS including OS setup, installation, and useful tools.

sections.title: Operating System
sections.content: Robotics Development relies heavily on Linux. We recommend using Ubuntu 18.04 since it is the most widely used and supported variant. Options include dual booting, virtual machines, or WSL for Windows users.

sections.title: Installing ROS
sections.content: Different versions of Ubuntu need different variants of ROS. Ubuntu 18.04 uses ROS Melodic, Ubuntu 16.04 uses ROS Kinetic.

sections.title: Useful Tools
sections.content: Essential tools include Git for version control, Terminator for multiple terminals, and VS Code for code editing.
sections.code:
sudo apt install git
sudo apt install terminator

articles.title: Getting Started with ROS
articles.excerpt: Learn the fundamentals of Robot Operating System including nodes, topics, publishers, subscribers, and services.

sections.title: What is ROS?
sections.content: ROS is a collection of tools and frameworks which make automating robotics projects much easier. A ROS system can be visualized as a graph where vertices are nodes (programs performing tasks) and edges are topics (channels for message exchange).

sections.title: Basic Concepts
sections.content: Key concepts include: Catkin (build system), Workspace (directory containing packages), Packages (organized code units), Nodes (executable programs), Topics (communication channels), Publishers/Subscribers (for async data exchange), and Services (for request-response patterns).

sections.title: Getting Things Running
sections.content: Use 'roscore' to start ROS Master, 'rosrun' to execute nodes, and 'roslaunch' to launch multiple nodes from a launch file.

references.text: Programming Robots with ROS by Morgan Quigley

articles.title: PID Controller
articles.excerpt: Proportional-Integral-Derivative control - the most widely used control technique in robotics and industry.

sections.title: PID Controller
sections.content: PID control is the most popular technique in industries because it is relatively easy to design and implement. The control law is: u(t) = Kp*e(t) + Ki*‚à´e(t) + Kd*de(t)/dt, where e is the error signal.

sections.title: Proportional Factor
sections.content: The output is the product of gain and measured error. Larger gain causes faster response but can lead to oscillation and steady-state offset.

sections.title: Integral Factor
sections.content: Eliminates steady-state error by accumulating past errors. Can contribute to overshoot if not tuned properly.

sections.title: Derivative Factor
sections.content: Improves closed-loop stability by predicting future error based on rate of change. Allows for more aggressive P and I tuning.

sections.title: Tuning Methods
sections.content: Trial and Error: Start with P, add I to reduce steady-state error, add D to reduce overshoot. Ziegler-Nichols: Systematic approach using critical gain and oscillation period.

articles.title: Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR)
articles.excerpt: Optimal control technique that minimizes a quadratic cost function for linear systems.

articles.title: Model Predictive Control (MPC)
articles.excerpt: Advanced control strategy using system models to predict future behavior and optimize control actions.

articles.title: Introduction to Electronics
articles.excerpt: Overview of electronics in robotics - microcontrollers, sensors, actuators, and interfacing.
articles.content: From interfacing microprocessors to making logical circuits, Robotics is incomplete without electronics. Every task that a Robot performs eventually boils down to some signal received by it. Most robots have a processing unit (Raspberry Pi, Nvidia Jetson, Arduino) that collects data from sensors and performs calculations. Common sensors include depth cameras, LIDAR, Encoders, and IMU.

articles.title: Arduino
articles.excerpt: Complete guide to Arduino - the most accessible microcontroller platform for beginners.

sections.title: Board Layout
sections.content: Arduino UNO features USB port for power/programming, power jack, voltage regulator, crystal oscillator (16MHz), reset button, digital I/O pins, analog pins (A0-A5), and the main ATmega328P microcontroller.

sections.title: The Blink Sketch
sections.content: The 'Hello World' of Arduino - blinks the onboard LED. Every sketch needs setup() (runs once) and loop() (runs repeatedly) functions.

sections.title: Programming
sections.content: Use Arduino IDE to write, compile, and upload code. Key functions: pinMode() for configuration, digitalWrite() for output, analogRead() for reading sensors, and Serial for communication.

articles.title: ESP32
articles.excerpt: Powerful dual-core microcontroller with built-in WiFi and Bluetooth - nearly 10x faster than Arduino Uno.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: ESP32 is a dual-core 32-bit MCU with integrated Wi-Fi and Bluetooth. It runs at 160/240 MHz (vs Arduino's 16 MHz), has 512KB RAM (vs 2KB), and 36 GPIO pins with support for ADC, DAC, SPI, I2C, UART, and more.

sections.title: Features
sections.content: 18 ADC channels (12-bit), 2 DAC channels, 10 capacitive touch sensors, 3 SPI channels, 2 I2C interfaces, 16 PWM channels, and Hall effect sensor.

sections.title: Programming
sections.content: Can be programmed using Arduino IDE, PlatformIO, MicroPython, Lua, or Espressif IDF. Arduino IDE setup is similar to regular Arduino with additional board support.

articles.content: Mechanical aspects of robotics involve designing, building and testing mechanical sensors and devices. This includes robot configuration, joint mechanisms, axes, heat transfer, and mounting positions. CAD software is used for design, and solving kinematics/dynamics equations is essential for robot tasks.
